title: Video Game Addiction Tries to Move From Basement to Doctor's Office

embed.description: Video games work hard to hook players. Designers use predictive algorithms and principles of behavioral economics to keep fans engaged. When new games are reviewed, the most flattering accolade might be "I can't put it down." Now, the World Health Organization is saying players can actually become addicted.

body: I want to hear the league of legends communities feelings upon this matter, so I'm going to drop this little ounce of information here and sit back and watch and discuss the conversation with you.

replies.body: While they can be addictive, and it can cause frustration and aggressive mood swings if you're not allowed to play, they're only minorly addictive. They're nowhere near as addictive as substances, and "coming off" video games is not only quicker, but not actually damaging to the body like coming off a substance can be. It's a mental fixation more than anything, and it can typically be corrected with time spent away from games - like a vacation, or a trip, or anything that gets you out of the house. I don't think they need to be classified as addictions like substances nor treated as such.

Life is a balance. 

People can become too addicted to anything to the point where it negatively impacts their life. Someone could be addicted to things that are good for them, such as being addicted to work or working out, but if too many eggs are placed in one basket, it can have a negative toll on the other aspects of one's life. Likewise, gaming has some genuine mental benefits, but there are cons to every pro, and too much overindulgence without restraint is never a good thing, regardless if that thing is gaming or something else.

As someone who doesn't really enjoy the game and kinda uninstall it frequently, what keeps me hooked (and sadly I don't even want to) is the release of new content pretty frequently. Such as new items, champions getting reworked, new champions, new game modes etc.
Like who would have resisted when they saw {{champion:142}} 's teaser (my game was uninstalled for a month at that time) and I think THIS kind of strategy is what keeps players hooked

video games aren't addictive.

addicting video game mechanics are addictive.

there's a minor, but very important distinction that needs to be made about that fact. otherwise we're slapping a disgusting label on all video games. and we shouldnt do that.

video games are digital forms of entertainment. no one would argue that playing digital monopoly is addicting. nor would they say that playing the walking dead season 1 is addicting either.

in fact most decent games arent addicting at all because they have a beginning and an end. the only games that are addicting are games that are open ended with grind based mechanics and zero story closure to be found.

and the honest truth is that video games arent addicting to normal people. they're addicting to people who are susceptible to gambling and similar mechanics.
